title: Jhin is a Great Addition to the Lore
body: It has been a while since we had a true villain. And those you can classify as villains usually have incredibly broad goals that aren't realistic for them to accomplish. Jihn seems to have one goals, kill someone that he deems "worthy", and he seems extremely competent at achieving that goal time and time again if we go his VO. It's pretty eerie to think that a man like that is in Runeterra right now planning to kill one of your favorite champions. He serves as a nice wildcard.

replies.body: He's bad, but not a myth. We knew we wanted to do a new villian and from a place under-represented for badguys.  With the intention of showing a different side of that society, while giving our characters an antagonist.   Internally alotta people like his lore.  I hope guys like it when it is released (soon).

And what makes it better is that he gives off that Amon (Legend of Korra)/Slade (Teen Titans) vibe. Or it might just be the mask, or maybe that kind of character is synonymous with scary masks.

He has that really intimidating calm voice.

He reminds me of Handsome Jack, in mask and a few mannerisms.

Most of all he seems like a character from Batman's Rogue's Gallery and his movements remind me of the Joker in Injustice: Gods Among Us.
picture jihn sounding more crude and annoyed as he gets lower health just like jack!{{sticker:zombie-brand-mindblown}}

So why would you consider {{champion:223}} not a true villain/his goals to broad?
All he really cares about is making others suffer through his deals,that doesn't really strike me as "too broad"

I would say this because his actions take years to show their consequences and he only seems to be able to do it to one person at a time. To be fair, there could be multiple demons like the one that possessed Tahm Kench, but Tahm Kench isn't multiple demons. I was hoping they would have Tahm Kench be the one who saved GP. This would have a cool doomed character dynamic, knowing that GP would never be the King of Bilgewater ever again (at least for long).

I think it is more on a case-to-case-basis of how long his actions need to show their effect.
In the case of the gambler it took years,because the gambler basically had to start from nothing to escape from his debts,so Tahm had to wait until the gambler had something that he did not want to loose again.
In other cases Tahm might be able to collect his debt a few days/weeks later.
He's another champion who could easily fit in with lore containing the Institute of War.
